it's just a group that has the experience of having
fought with the Milice and the gendarmerie for months,

who were trained by the soldiers who
were there for two months,

who're pretty well armed 'cause
they'd hidden some weapons for themselves,

and who just spent the last two months
listening to the BBC reminding them that,

to fight back, yeah, you've gotta have
the equipment, the organisation, the weapons,

that's all really important, but honestly, the only
thing you really need is the will to fight back.

This unit starts to ambush the German
patrols to take their equipment,

they blow up police stations to recover
the letters of denunciation in them,

they derail trains that transport stuff
for Hitler, but it's not just this unit.

What's interesting is that a few weeks later,
we hear of another group near Thônes,

on the other side of the valley,
that's doing exactly the same thing.
Then another... and another... and another.

They weren't all at the Glières,
but they'd all heard about it.

Starting in spring, the movement
gains a lot of traction.

Like, a few months later, it's no longer possible for
the Third Reich to send a train through Haute-Savoie.
25 locomotives were derailed in the region in 1944.
Which means that when summer arrived,

Hitler knew that there was no point in sending
a train to the region, it wouldn't get through.

Same for production, the most important thing
for Hitler in Haute-Savoie was the S.R.O.
it's the biggest factory in Annecy,

this huge thing with hundreds of workers
that made tanks for the Wehrmacht.

The Allies had been trying to destroy
the S.R.O. since the start of the war,

but they never managed to be
precise enough when bombing it,

they didn't have the planes and bombs of today,
it was incredibly hard to be accurate.

On the 10th of May, the Savoyard
Resistance infiltrates the city,
stealthily eliminate the GMRs guarding the S.R.O.

and mark the roof, the station
and the telephone exchange...
and disappear.

And an hour later,
30 English bombers, who'd been notified,

arrive and blow up all the buildings
in Annecy that were still useful to Hitler.

And in the end, the new leader of the Milice
in the region is forced to write to Paris to say

"Um, so regarding Haute-Savoie, the situation's worse
than before our operations against the Maquis."

There's even places that the powers
of Vichy and Germany don't dare go anymore,

notably Thorens which is a really,
really important area,

the village at the bottom of the Glières where
loads of kids died the day they tried to escape.

On the 14th of July, the Resistance
organised a parade in Thorens...

and the region was so dangerous for
the government that no one came to stop them.

By the way, from July onwards, the
Resistance considered Thorens as liberated,

no one from Vichy or the Third Reich
would ever set foot there again.

And in the meantime, the Allies had landed
in Normandy, meaning that they weren't that far,
(15th of August 1944)

and there might be a way to get more weapons,
especially since the Allies were pretty trusting
of the Resistance in the area after all the sacrifices they had made.

And when the Americans offer to send 20 bombers to drop
more weapons than the two previous drops put together...

symbolically, where do they go to
to receive the weapons?

And so, in August, 3000 people went up in
broad daylight, without hiding themselves,
to where Tom Morel's grave is,

and watched the American bombers drop
more weapons than Haute-Savoie had ever seen.

A few days after the Resistance
receives the weapons...

the Germans in Thonon, in the north
of Haute-Savoie, realise that something's up.

They realise that something's up 'cause the Vichy
subprefect from that town had disappeared...
he'd been kidnapped by the Resistance.

And as they feel like something's about
to happen, they call for reinforcements,

and the day after, they're told that the trucks
that should've come with the SS reinforcements
had mysteriously exploded in another town.

And the next day,
the telephone lines in Thonon get cut,
and the day after that, the water gets cut off.

And then they try to go on a sortie and realise that
the town's surrounded, and Thonon falls that day.

And now, it's nothing like a valley or
a village like Thorens anymore, it's a town,

it's honestly a big town in Haute-Savoie
that's just fallen... that's just been re-taken.

And there's places where, knowing that
the western front is coming towards you,

and you can't retreat 'cause
the Resistance has sieged the town,

and you can't call for help
'cause they cut your communication,

the pressure is so high that
there's towns that surrender.
In Evian, 800 soldiers surrendered.

And more and more towns fall,
like Cluses and Chamonix and suddenly,

the situation changes so quickly
that all eyes turn to Annecy.
And after all these years of fighting, you might not want to risk your life again
you know that the Western front is progressing,

you know that a professional army will
probably arrive and liberate Annecy at any point.

But your family's still there...
your mates are still in prison,

and the Germans who feel like they're losing
control, are killing more and more.
So what do you do?

That's why, 80 years later, there's a monument on the
Glières plateau precisely where Tom Morel was buried.

It's not a monument for the dead...
it's a monument for the glory of the Resistance.

It's there to remind us that when the first Liberation
Army that came from Provence arrived at the Alps,

the German garrison in Annecy
had already surrendered.
It's there to remind us...
that Haute-Savoie had liberated itself.

Le jeu où on plante des sapins.text:
The first time you start "Terra Nil",
you're given a map that's dead and sad,

and you've got a limited number
of buildings to salvage things.

This is where you need to start using your head,
'cause each building's got a specific set of rules;
the Turbine can only go on hard ground,

the Toxin Scrubber needs to go next
to a Turbine 'cause it needs electricity,

and the Irrigator only works on soil
that's been cleaned by the Toxin Scrubber.

So it's a pain, but when you manage...
to place Turbines near each other
and get electricity exactly where you need it,

and you perfectly place two Toxin
Scrubbers to get a huge line of arable land,
and you place the perfect Irrigator...
it's goddamn satisfying.

'Cause for each move,
sure, you pay for the building,

but you also get rewarded according to
the amount of nature you revitalise,
and it can be more than the price of the building,

so, in this game, the better
your move is strategically...
the more it becomes eye candy.

And the further you get through the game, the more
these moves will require a bit of forward-thinking.
Y'see this area?

When I placed this Irrigator earlier, I didn't
place it randomly where I needed grass,

I placed it so it was in the middle of
an area where there'd be plenty of water,

like, I don't need this dry river in
the middle, I've technically already got grass,
but I'll still revive it... I'll still add water,

'cause now there's lots of tiles here which are
considered by the game to be waterlogged,

which means they're close to a river, and when I
buy the Hydroponium, which is an upgraded Irrigator,

all the waterlogged tiles in range
of the Irrigator change type.
And seeing as I've prepared the area in advance,

I'll bring back a lot of diversity with
the purchase of a single building.

Same here, I can make a
field grow, build a Solar Amplifier,
use the Solar Amplifier to set the field on fire...
except, instead of burning the entire map,

I've got a controlled burn 'cause I dug tunnels
and made a swamp ahead of time,
which are things that naturally stop the fire.
So I've got ash, but only in the area I wanted,

and the Solar Amplifier I placed earlier
burned in the fire, but that was also planned,

'cause the old ruin of a burned building plus ash
lets me place the building that makes forests.

This game is honestly for those
who love planning five moves ahead,

and who'd love the reward
when it all comes together of uh,

it's so cute, it's so pretty,
it's so soothing, it's so relaxing.
Unfortunately...
the further I get, the more frustrated I become,
'cause, it's a game I bought for its strategy,

but it's also a game I bought to make
the most beautiful map possible,

and y'see all these areas at the edge
and even the small areas further in,
one tile, three tiles, I'll never recover them.

There's always little bits of the map that're
just out of range of the building to the left,

just out of range of the building to the right, and I
could redo the map 100 times, it would be the same.

And it's a resource management game, so if I pay
full price for a building to recover three tiles,
and I do that twice, I'll go bankrupt.

And these places stay as they are while the rest of
the map becomes more and more incredible...

'cause the places I managed to
detoxify now have chain reactions.

As I placed more and more
plants, the temperature rose,

which attracted animals, and they
also then enhanced the land.

And as I added swamps and rivers,
the humidity in the air increased,
which made mushrooms grow in the forests,

which then brought in new animals,
which enhanced the land even more.

And the first time YOU go and play "Terra Nil",
you're going to see all this beauty...
and each time you zoom out,

you're going to see all these polluted areas that
you can't do a goddamn thing about, and it's awful.

And look, this strip of land
at the top, for example,

if I wanted to salvage it, I'd
have to place 7 or 8 buildings.

You've got to place a Cannon,
make a trench, get water,

use the water to create rock,
use the rock to make electricity,

use the electricity to place factories, and it's
only then that we can maybe start getting grass.

And it's only doable 'cause it's a strip of land,
but there's no way we do the same thing here,

we're not going to place
8 buildings for 4 tiles of land.

And so I was continuing with my
first game of "Terra Nil" saying

"Okay, I'll try my best, I'll get the
best score possible, and at the end, well,

there'll be 10% of the map
that'll look like nothing, too bad...

a bit surprising for a game uh, that we pretty
much buy for the aesthetics, but whatever."
The game's got a solution of course...

which is really simple, and really
elegant, and really obvious,

and I should've known
now that I think about it, but...

the clue is: the chain reactions
we've been causing since the start.

If I can create a swamp to the
north and the humidity increases,

and it makes a mushroom grow in the forest
to the south, then the game's telling me

"Uh, you're not trying to focus on this area,
or that area, you're trying to revive the ecosystem."

And so, after spending an hour trying to get
this planet going again, the planet said uh
"Thank you very much, I'll take care of the rest."

(With ekwator)
(Green energy provider)

"Uh, you're giving CoD to whoever,
so we want to be known for another franchise,
we want to separate Modern Warfare from CoD."
And every week, Activision sent an email saying
"Guys, you really need to call the new game CoD."

and every week, they posted a new video called
"Modern Warfare 2" and it made Activision go nuts.

Unfortunately, we'll never have the pleasure
of hearing a judge say who was right,
'cause, once again, it didn't go to trial.

One day, everyone showed up saying
"Y'know what, we've come to an agreement."

And we'll never know what that agreement was,
'cause they obviously all signed NDAs.

Now, there's only one thing
that could've actually happened...

only one thing could've happened,
Bobby paid his ex-employees millions of dollars,

so they'd drop the matter with
"CoD" once and for all.

And ex-Infinity Ward employees
could've probably made billions,

rather than millions,
if they'd gone through with the trial,

but they couldn't afford to continue the legal battle
against all of Bobby's lawyers for 10 years, why?
'Cause they had a new assignment, a new objective.

They'd, once again, gathered around West
and Zampella, in a new studio called Respawn,

and they wanted to do what
they'd already achieved before,

create a new franchise that was so sick
that it would make people forget "CoD",

in the same way they'd already
made people forget "Medal of Honor".

They started with "Titanfall", which was
an Xbox exclusive and had no campaign,
it didn't stand a chance, but it was a good try,

and then they made "Titanfall 2" which,
in my opinion, is the best FPS ever made.

It's one of the rare games I think is perfect,
I wouldn't mess with the blueprint if I could,

I think it's mathematically impossible
to be bored when playing "Titanfall 2".
The idea behind "Titanfall" was very basic, it was,
"CoD was two things, running and shooting,

now that we've spent 10 years
perfecting shooting, let's perfect running...

so let's make a game where
simply moving around the map is fun,
let's make a game where movement is so technical,

so beautiful and so enjoyable that people could
make videos on YouTube where they're just moving...
not shooting anyone, just moving to chill music."

You honestly shoot like in "CoD", except,
as you're always in the air or running on a wall,

any kill looks insane, and the depth of gameplay
is twice as good 'cause suddenly, the question

"Do you have good movement?"
is as important as "Do you have good aim?"

Even though it's really fast-paced and extremely
precise, it's perfectly playable on controller,

and there's titans... they added titans
to separate themselves a bit from "CoD"

and they actually change the dynamic
quite a bit, but you can play without the titans,

and without the titans, it's honestly just
the best version of an FPS on console ever.

Now, of course, it's been years since the release
of this game, everyone still knows "CoD"

and pretty much no one's played "Titanfall",
so something must've happened.

What happened was that, while they were working
on "Titanfall 2", Activision obviously didn't stop.
Bobby knew exactly what "Titanfall" would look like.

It'd been years since Infinity Ward pitched
the game to him and said "Please let us make it."

and what's more, everyone who'd left Infinity Ward,
and those who'd stayed, knew each other,

they all spoke to each other, Activision knew
full well what Respawn was making.

So now, your old team, who's extremely dangerous,
is vying for the top spot by doing a futuristic "CoD",

with grappling hooks and jetpacks,
what would be your best move?

Take your franchise that's 100 times more famous,
and add grappling hooks and jetpacks.

"Advanced Warfare", the first
futuristic "CoD", was released in 2014,

which means they started developing it straight
after the original Infinity Ward team left.

The year after, "Black Ops 3", futuristic again,
jetpacks, grappling hooks, all of that,

and the year after that,
"Infinite Warfare", again, the same thing.

At that point, "CoD" fans started to
go nuts 'cause from one year to the next,

they were used to a certain variety,
a game about the Cold War and then the year after,

a game about modern warfare, and here,
there'd been 3 straight years of games set in 2050,

with guys who can jump
two metres high and walk on walls.

When they saw that "Infinite Warfare" was set
in 2050 again, with grappling hooks and jetpacks,

the trailer became one of the most
disliked in the history of YouTube.

And "CoD" sold 10 million copies less than before
in that period, which is a lot, even for them,

but it didn't matter 'cause when
you see the world like Bobby,
all you need is the privilege the top spot gives you,

where you just have to release an okay game
every year to sell at least 15 million copies,
that's what you've got to cling on to,

and the worst-case scenario for you isn't losing
10 million players, the worst-case scenario is;

you're making a game about
the Cold War, as usual, and suddenly,

a new studio that no one's ever heard of releases
something fresh, and that we've never seen before,

it's "CoD" but uh, in the future, you can
walk on walls and jump really, really high,

and it's fresh enough and new enough
that loads of people try it out...

and they'd discover that the jetpack isn't just to
jump 2 metres high and run on walls for 3 seconds,

it's a mechanic that takes 100s of hours to master
and turns you into Superman once you get it...

they'd discover that the maps aren't the usual
"CoD" maps with 5 extra walls for wall running,

but are entirely designed
around the new movement mechanic,

and are literally just theme parks filled
with launch pads that you can take off from.

At the same time, they'd discover that
balancing is less of an issue in this game,

'cause if you're better at
movement than anyone else in the game,

it doesn't matter what weapon
you're using, you're lethal no matter what.
Then, if you're unfortunate,

word of mouth would make so much noise that in
November the following year, you'd no longer be number 1.

That's the worst-case scenario...
that's the one thing to avoid at all costs,

even if you've got to make
the same game 3 years in a row.

So yeah, when "Infinite Warfare" came out
in 2016, it only sold 15 million copies,

which is extremely low for a "CoD", but it
came out at the same time as "Titanfall 2" which,

in everyone's eyes, looked like an umpteenth
"CoD" with jetpacks, and it sold 4 million copies...

and "Titanfall" never recovered, and to
this day, there's still no "Titanfall 3".

And the rivalry between Bobby and his former employees
continues to this day with "Warzone" and "Apex".

The problem is, "Warzone" is 10 times bigger than
"Apex" 'cause it's based on "CoD", which is huge,
while "Apex" is based on "Titanfall", which flopped.
So, did Bobby come out on top in this story?

Well, he realised straight away that EA had just
ditched the most talented team in the world,

he bought them for 5 million,
they started making a successful franchise,
and when they were about to revolt and jump ship,

he lied to them just long enough so they'd
make him the biggest publisher in the world.

And when that team came back to
take the top spot four years later,

he shattered their dreams... by screwing up
their ideas for 3 years straight.

Now, I can't help thinking that
if it had been called "CoD",

everyone would've been able to discover it,
and of course, some players wouldn't've liked it,

but everyone would've seen that "CoD" was more ambitious
than ever, and the media and gamers would've said

"Look, even though they're already at the top,
Infinity Ward continues to do what they've always done,

they try new things, even though they don't
need to, like when they stopped using World War II,
and above all, they always raise the bar."

And Bobby's wallet probably
would've grown more in the long run,

'cause it's never bad for business
to wow the whole world.

Instead, "CoD" sat on its laurels in the top spot
and continued to slowly lose players,

and of course, sales didn't improve
when they dropped the jetpack,

'cause the problem wasn't
players being fed up with the jetpack,

it was players being fed up of
playing the same game all the time,

and the jetpack was so poorly implemented
that it didn't change a thing.
So, we saw the fall of "CoD",
"Titanfall" was forgotten,

and we got 10 years of "CoD" YouTubers
making the same fucking video like
"Oh my god, what happened to Infinity Ward?"

'cause they never understood
that a studio's name means nothing,
it's way too easy to change who works for a company,

and if they'd just taken 2 minutes to look at
the only thing that's important, the end credits...

they would've known that the people who made
their favourite childhood games had left in 2009.

So I don't think Bobby's
the overall winner in this story,

I think he's just the one who lost the least,
I think if Infinity Ward and Bobby had got along...

the last 10 years of FPS games
would've been way more interesting.
There we go, I hope you liked it.

A huge thank you to everyone who's already joined
the Patreon, to everyone who shares and watches,

it's a lot of work, but you've always been
really good to me, so I'm very lucky,
(Thank you!)

and a huge thank you to Top Achat as well,
they sponsor a part of these videos
and agree to do so in an unconventional way,

without interrupting the story,
which is rare from a sponsor.

I've put their link in the description,
buy something from them if you can,

'cause they really look after me,
and... yeah... till next time.
Translation and subtitles by TheDøctør

La plus belle des équipes.text:
Get closer ladies and gents,
today I'm telling the most beautiful,

the most terrible, the most tragic
story of "League of Legends" (LoL).

Incidentally, this story
contains the greatest match played

and it makes me happy as I’ve
been wanting to tell it for ages.
Today, we're talking about the ROX Tigers.

If you’ve never played "LoL",
it won't be too hard to follow,

it’s a story of friendship and perseverance,
not of who bought the best item at minute 8.
And there’s not much you need to know,

the first team to destroy the
rock in the enemy’s base wins.

So, everyone spends 20
minutes roaming around the map,

killing the critters and enemy players
they come across, not specifically to win,

but to become strong enough to
enter their base and destroy the big rock.
There’s nothing else to know about "LoL".
Okay, we’re in... Korea...

the country that doesn't hesitate to
proclaim that everything's a competition,
where companies close on the day of finals

as the whole country agrees that the younger
generations' future is determined that day,

where competition in gaming was already
accepted and taken seriously 15 years ago,

when even now, we still need
to explain it here on the radio.

When a country like that, with such a competitive
culture and a corresponding love for gaming
got their hands on "LoL", it went really really well,

they became the best in the
world in a year and a half.
They won the world championship once, then twice,

then the Europeans asked themselves
if they were ever going to win again.

But out of nowhere in 2015... the prestigious
Korean league called the LCK is shaken up,

they change the rules, and not
just a bit, they go from 16 teams to 8.
Why? 'Cause all the big sponsors had two teams,

and it was starting to become
complicated to explain to the public

that there wasn't a conflict of interest
when Samsung’s first team faced their second team.

And so, out of nowhere, all of the big
orgs had to fire half of their workforce.

It was havoc, never before had so
many people lost their contracts at once.
In the middle of this chaos, GorillA,

who's considered to be one of
the best supports in the world

and lucky enough that his org
wants to keep him, decides to leave.
He doesn’t get along with his superiors anymore

and tells himself they
won’t let him do what he wants.

And so, even though he was
safe, he decides to join Huya...

which is a Chinese streaming
platform trying to launch in Korea,

they've got almost no budget
and want to finance a "LoL" team

and as GorillA's the star player, he's got
the right to choose the other players.

Problem... no one's going to transfer
from a prestigious org to join Huya.
No chance.

We could say that a huge
number of people just got fired,

it’s perfect, there'll be lots of star
players that don’t have a contract,

except it’s at this moment, the rest of
the world has started to pillage the LCK,

so anyone decent has already
signed in China, the US or Europe.
And again, there’s not much money at Huya,

so GorillA needs to fill a team with
players that were abandoned by their org,

that no other region on Earth wants
and that're prepared to work for pennies.
It’s perfect.
Enter the protagonists of the story.

Lee's a player who's invisible,
he’s been playing for multiple seasons,
but hasn’t left a lasting impression on anyone.

Kuro's okay, but he always found
himself in teams that achieved nothing...

and as he’s not exceptional enough to
carry the other four to victory, in people’s eyes,

he’s always been the least lousy player
in a team that accomplished nothing.
Pray, on the other hand... everyone knows him.

He's a great player, he’s even
won the LCK before, the problem is,

it's been several years
since he accomplished anything
and globally, the fans think he should be retired.
Lee and Kuro aren't too hard to convince,

'cause GorillA's the last person
on Earth that sees something in them.
Pray's problem is that he agrees with the fans...
he thinks he's old and his glory days are over...
and GorillA scouts him saying,

"Listen, in 2012 I watched you play,
I wasn't even a professional player yet...

I've always been a fan of yours, I've
always dreamed of playing with you...

and above all, I think the Pray of 2012
that smashed everyone is still around."

He managed to convince
him to sign for one more year,
even though he was already ready to retire.
So they’re 4...
but "LoL" is played as 5...

they don't really have an idea for the last one
yet and it's Kuro that suggests a young player...

and even in this team of
misfits that's being formed,

when he suggests the name,
everyone says "Nah bro, not him."

And SMEB's a very young player
that had a catastrophic first season,
the first team he joined benched him after 6 months
'cause he was getting massacred by everyone.
So the team tells him,

"Bro, SMEB's got bigger problems
than being a bit old or invisible...
he's considered the worst Top laner in the league."
But in the same way that GorillA believes in Pray...
Kuro believes in SMEB.

And at the end of the day, the person
that GorillA really wanted for this position

announced that ultimately,
they’re going to play in Europe

and so Lee, Kuro, Pray, GorillA
and SMEB become the Huya Tigers.
It's not ROX Tigers yet, but we're getting there.

In a way that's extremely
foreboding or extremely unlucky,
the first opponent they face in an LCK match is SKT.
At the time, SKT was the monster under your bed,

an old and prestigious organisation at the centre
of eSports in Korea since the days of "Starcraft",

the first to have won a world
championship title for their country as well

and at the time when the Chinese teams were trying
to poach the best players from the Korean orgs,
they managed to keep Faker...

and Faker in 2015 is more of
a living God than a "LoL" player.

Faker's just spent the entire winter refusing
offers worth several million to play in Shanghai,

he wants only one thing, a second
world championship title for SKT

and he's ready to devour the first
unfortunate person to get in his way

and the first unfortunate people
to stand in his way are the Huya Tigers,

with their grey jumpers as they’re
behind schedule and don't have a uniform.

They get annihilated, it’s a game where
we saw Faker die on purpose for laughs.

It’s a game where sadly,
SMEB got chased in an area of the map,
even though it was over 15 minutes earlier.
It was a massacre.

Now, exceptionally, the league had
organised a few weeks of pre-season

so the orgs could get used to the changes,
so this match didn’t count towards the points,

but you enter the most competitive
league in the world with your new team

that must prove itself and...
you pose absolutely no threat
that the opponents joke around for 10 minutes?

Mentally it’s a catastrophe and the fans
and the media had seen what they'd come to see.

The next day, as the Tigers only had
players that matured in the LCK,
there's a big Korean site that writes,

"Huya Tigers, the team with a
ton of experience but no skill."

And the catastrophe's not over,
they changed their name at the last second,
ultimately they won't be the Huya Tigers,
but the GE Tigers for the rest of the season.
It's still the same company that manages them,

but they decided to promote
another product, what does this mean?

It means that Huya didn't
work, it didn't work at all.

The problem is, in Korea, the sponsor that
gives its name to your team pays for everything,

the quality of your accommodation,
your equipment and your salary

depend on how much money
they want to put into the team.
If you start changing names every 3 weeks

'cause the product you're
meant to promote isn't selling,
it's a disaster for your financial future.

So, not only they're awful, not only
they're the laughingstock of everyone,

they’re probably broke too, they've most
likely got fewer resources than the other teams.
This team's a disaster.
Why even do a video about them?
'Cause they're the most beautiful team in the world.

'Cause when the pre-season
ended and the games started to count...

they started smashing teams that
were 5 times better than them on paper
by playing a chaotic and unpredictable "LoL"...

and by being a bunch of happy
idiots that sang before the match...
and that came to official games wearing cat ears.

They weren't singing to entertain
the crowd, yeah, but to calm their nerves,

and they started doing the
costume thing 'cause their coach, NoFe...

the guy in the coat that’s
selecting their champions, told them,

"Listen, currently, you're two unknowns,
a has-been, a failure and GorillA...

no one supports you, it's sad but it's true,
no one supports you and yet you need it,

it'll be easier to get on this stage
every week if there's at least two people
screaming when you're announced, not like now...

so you're going to do everything
you can to touch people's hearts

and if that means wearing different funny
outfits every week, great, I’ll join you."

And NoFe was right, once people decide
you suck, it's not easy to change their minds.

Week 1 they won against IM and people said
"Yes but IM suck, it means nothing."

Week 2 they won against Samsung and people
said, "Yes but Samsung only have beginners,

they don't have the
experience yet, it means nothing."

Week 3 they won against
Jin Air, which, by all means,
is an extremely solid team and what did they say?

They said, "Honestly, it was close,
it could've easily been Jin Air."

Except, you see this
caterpillar scaring Jin Air away?

It's Kog'Maw, it's a champion that
does a ton of damage, but is very fragile,
the Tigers are trying to use it as bait,

'cause the other champions they chose
alongside it give shields and resistances,

so the enemies jump on the
caterpillar thinking they’ll kill it
the caterpillar doesn’t die and it rips them apart.
It's a strategy called JuggerMaw.

Known for years, yeah, it's
been played on the five continents...
and was invented...
by the Tigers...
that day, against Jin Air.
In 3 months it's a strategy used everywhere, okay;

Berlin, Shanghai, Los Angeles, it's
the first time we see it in competition...

and all that the casters
manage to say for 5 minutes is,

"Frankly, Jin Air fans shouldn't be
sad because it was so close."

That's not the only thing they brought to
"Summoner's Rift", they were super inventive,

they took an item called the Banner of
Command, a stupid item that's existed for years,

that no one dared take in competitive
play, it's used to strengthen a minion
on the map to attack the enemy's towers...
they bought not one but two... and they won with it?
Partly 'cause NoFe was evil

and partly 'cause they were willing
to play anything as long as it was fun,

they were very, very
unpredictable in their strategy.

It's difficult to explain
to those who don't play "LoL",
but they won professional games in the LCK with;
Sion Mid, Mundo Jungle and Urgot ADC...

and their Urgot ADC became a
classic throughout the rest of 2015.

Okay, but how's it possible for a team that
wasn't capable of playing normal "LoL" the previous year,

to suddenly manage to get results
with such an unorthodox "LoL"?

So, in their first loss in pre-season
they'd known each other for 2 weeks...

since then, they had time to realise
that they were united by something;
they were fed up of having fallen to the bottom...
"I think everyone felt a certain resentment,
we had all experienced failure."
...and they had the same personalities,
partly extremely hardworking and partly idiotic.

And now you're going to say "Augustin,
don't tell me you're trying to argue that

they began to perform at the highest
level of LoL due to the power of friendship."
It's not that stupid... it's not that stupid.
To explain, here's Kuro at a Korean restaurant...

"Apparently, on other teams, the
players live their own lives outside of training,

but we became friends as soon
as we found ourselves together.

It's important 'cause LoL is a team game,
the team has to do everything together

and when you play alone, even a good idea
on paper isn't going to work... so it's important."
The Tigers often lose the start of the game.

Individually, they're usually weaker
than their opponents in the same role.

And you know what, in the late game, where you
need to move as one and react at the same time,

they win, not only do they win every time,
but they win even though they’re behind.

There's something else that this incredible
synergy allows you to manage... pressure.

At what per cent of your max
are you, good or bad, yeah,

at what per cent of your max
are you when you're on stage,

the spotlights turn on, the country's
watching and your career's on the line?

The answer varies greatly from one day to
the next and it can make or break careers.

Being surrounded by 4 people
that obviously work 18 hours a day,

but also make you feel like
you're with your friends...

can create this illusion that you're playing
stress-free, that's an extraordinary power.

So they rely on this incredible
synergy to win no matter what,

but there's a place on the map they never lose,
not at the beginning nor at the end;

the Top of the map, 'cause Lee...
Lee's the team's Jungler,
his role is to traverse the map helping the others.

In all the games at the start of the
2015 season, you can watch them all,

Lee always plays towards the top of
the map... 'cause in Top he's got SMEB.

Even in a team where everyone
wants to get back at the LCK...

SMEB's probably the one
that's got the most to prove.

When he told his parents he wanted
to become a professional player,
his dad didn't speak to him for a month.

His dad should've seen it coming
though 'cause every other evening,

when he was little, SMEB
didn't come home by nightfall,

and it was his dad that had to go
pick him up at the local supermarket,

'cause in Korea, in these little shops,
there are self-serv game consoles.

The same SMEB that told
his teachers his granddad died

so he could leave class
early to go to the cybercafé.
He was uncontrollable, he was a bright kid too,

that grasped things very quickly
and was highly competitive,

straight away he had to become
the best at everything he did,

especially the things he liked,
so every time a new game came out,

3 weeks later he was the terror of the cybercafé,
the terror of the neighbourhood and so,

logically, when "LoL" came out,
he ended up being scouted by an LCK team.

And there, his family said "No... you’re
way too young, you’re 17 years old uh,
we've let you get away with messing about so far,

but quitting your studies at 17 to
go play LoL is out of the question."

It took for his big brother, the sensible
child of the family, to negotiate for him,

he went to his parents saying, "Don't you
realise he's got an extraordinary talent,

he could do something with it." so
he had the right to join an LCK team at 17,
but on one condition: he can't quit his studies

and he has to finish his
A-levels at the same time.

It’s not meant to be possible,
both are full-time jobs,

but SMEB wanted it so much that he went to school,
in the evening he went to his team's premises,

practising "LoL" all night and at dawn
he went home to sleep for 2 to 3 hours,

then went back to school...
he did that until he graduated.

The problem is, being a young gaming prodigy
doesn't make you special when you get to the LCK,
it’s the prerequisite to join the LCK,
he was young, had no experience

and was living on 3 hours of
sleep a night... he got demolished.

And it’s certain that at 17, he didn't
have the mental strength to tank the fans

and the media that very quickly isolated
him as the reason that his team couldn’t win.

It went so badly, that he was
benched after 6 months...
and then fired.

And here he must've said to himself,
"I gave a year and a half of my life to this...

my brother convinced my
parents for me and yet here I am"...
which is when... he received a call from Kuro.
Apparently, there’s a team that still wants him...

and this team that's technically just
inherited the worst Top laner in the league,
they put all the resources on him,

they sent the Jungler to play around
him so that this guy who's got potential,

but whose confidence in himself was wiped
out by the LCK, doesn't have a single. bad. game.
And what happened when the Tigers believed in him?
SMEB started carrying games.
And in the 6th week of competition...
they faced SKT again...
and Lee played towards Top getting SMEB ahead,
and 25 minutes later it was SMEB all by himself,

on an unkillable Mundo,
that made all of SKT back away...
and in the end, when he received match MVP,

he dedicated it to his big
brother who was in the crowd.

Slowly but surely, people were saying,
"There's something interesting here."

Since earlier I've been saying
they do well at this or that,
but want to know exactly how much they've won?

Well, after their first loss
in pre-season against SKT,
the second time they lost...
was...
2 weeks from the end of the season...
they played pretty much 3 months without losing.

But even when they were 14-0 in
the season, they continued to do absurd stuff,

the videos that I'm showing you
aren't for a collab with a brand yeah, it's...
they just felt like making them.

Now, if all you do is win, eventually
you’ll find yourself in the play-off finals.

For those of you who hate sports,
play-offs are the big end-of-season tournament,

we take the teams that got
the best results of the season,

we put them in a tournament and the
winner is the overall winner of the season.
Of course, the finals are against SKT...
and the level of pressure's not the same,

there’s 10 times the audience of a normal
match, even Korean politicians come...

and above all... it's time to find out if
your efforts in the season mean something

or if you'll be the second place
that everyone forgets.

You have to deal with the fact that
80% of the fans believe SKT will win
and that 3 quarters of the room is rooting for them.

There's this funny thing in Korea where the
2 teams throw jabs at each other before the final,

Faker takes the microphone and says, "I heard in an
interview that you're not going to ban my Leblanc...

but mate, we know it's not true, 'cause if
get my hands on her you're screwed."

It gave us another adorable moment
where an SKT player says "Well, for real,

no joke, who here's stressed?"
and three Tigers raise their hand.
But way more than pressure the real problem is,

you're not facing SKT in a mid-season
match that they can afford to lose,

you’re facing SKT in a match
where they give their all.
SKT's the clean and flawless "League of Legends" okay,
