'cause in New York it was "Oh, there was
a fight in the street, we're cancelling."

in Liverpool, it was "Oh, someone went up on
the roof, we're cancelling." and in Nantes...

"Yeah, yeah, yeah, like they tried to, well, burn
down the museum yesterday. Coffee's good, huh."

While preparing this video, I had the chance
to speak with the people of "Le Lieu Unique"

and since they're the ones that offered to help
Shia and knew that it was a shitshow,
they prepped well to receive the flag.

They protected their data
with redundancies and encryption,

established protocols to change
their passwords regularly,

redid all the badges and briefed their employees
on good practices to counter intrusion.
Remember when I said the only thing they could do
was build a fortress around the flag?

Well, they got it, a fortress
with a tower almost 40m tall

and staff that know it's not a normal exhibition
and that it's literally Tower Defense.
As "Le Lieu Unique" is also a bar and concert hall,

they've got a security team that's used to
removing people who are a bit too persistent,

perhaps more so than in a normal museum
and that's useful 'cause people tried to get in...

including one with a crowbar and one insisting
they voted left but still wanted to grab the flag.

One person managed to sneak
past everyone and ended up here.

It's a glass roof, which led to a panicked
security team shouting directions

at them for 30 minutes to avoid having
them fall 10m into an exhibition.

All these people are tryharding to get to the roof,
thinking that it'll be easier to climb afterwards,

but no, even once you're on the roof,
what's left, 20m of climbing?
On a smooth surface with overhangs?
At a height where if you slip you die,

knowing full well that everyone's seen you
and that you'll get caught on the way out anyway?
No, there's a reason why no one got near the flag...

it's that there's not much need for a
security team when gravity's on your side.

So yeah, there's still the long-distance options,
but they're either extremely difficult to set up

or extremely dangerous and everyone calmed down
a bit after the flamethrower drone made headlines.

Once again, being known
for grabbing the flag's cool,

being known for burning down a
museum with people potentially inside...
less so.

At this point, everyone seemed to have decided
at the same time that the treasure hunt was fun,

but maybe enough was enough, as if, for once,
the internet had managed to scare itself.

Fear, plus the fact that we're like 6,000 km
from the country that this flag concerns

and that at this point, it's been
10 months since Trump was elected,

it's surprising that the internet had
fixated on the same thing for so long.

At one point, the piece was lent to a Polish museum
which gave the interactive stream another shot,

but the thing with Poland is that, yeah,
there's definitely fewer pro-Trump trolls,

but there's also zero supporters of Shia's
initial project and so it was basically dead.
And then it came back to Nantes...
where it stayed...

and we saw, once again, that the only thing
you can never escape isn't the internet...
it's just time.

There's no moral to this story, whether
you go after Shia out of political opposition,

out of hatred 'cause he's Jewish or just
'cause it's funny, either way, it's wrong.

They did it 'cause they could, 'cause
the internet doesn't make people evil,

but it does give an honest picture of what
they're like when there's no consequences.

It was possible 'cause you
can find anything on the internet,

they could do it without consequences 'cause
you can be whoever you want on the internet,

things that'll likely disappear in the future
or at least be very severely limited.
But for a little while longer...
for better or worse...

the internet remains the greatest source of power
and freedom that's been given to everyone since...
forever.

And 50 years from now,
when that's no longer the case,

there'll be stories like this to remind us
how chaotic it was in the beginning

and what it was like when
it spilt over into real life.

Even the end of this story
is typical of the unstoppable
and incredibly immature side of the internet.

Shia got chased to 6 different cities,
but in the end,

he won by using the tactic that
any exasperated parent would use

to protect something from the
hands of an insufferable child...
he put it too high for anyone to reach.

The pyromaniac in Nantes was caught by the police.
(They got off lightly)

The flag stolen in Tennessee was found
when the FBI raided a well-known neo-Nazi.

The guy that wanted to say something
about the Holocaust reappeared a year later,

7000 km from New York on the Polish
stream to wish everyone a happy 4th of July.
Snake became a wrestler in WWE.

"Le Lieu Unique" lowered the flag on the day of
Joe Biden's inauguration, the 20th of January 2021.
Translation and subtitles by TheDøctør

Comment Among Us a explosé.text: "Among Us" is on every Twitch channel...
every YouTube channel...
and in all the Best-Ofs.

The most surprising thing about
"Among Us" is, it's not been released recently,

it's 2 years old and for the longest
time it remained completely unknown.

Also, in the beginning, it had so
few players that it almost died out.
The game's made by Innersloth,

a small American studio that very
clearly doesn't have the means to advertise,
so when "Among Us" was released in June 2018,

the same thing happened as with the majority
of indie games, it was ignored by the whole world.

With only around 15 players logged
into the game in the early days,
there was usually only one active lobby at a time,

so when a new player tried
the game for the first time,

they had to wait for the previous game
to finish to be able to play with people.

To avoid disaster, Innersloth lowers the
minimum number of players in a game to 4,
an impostor and 3 crewmates.

The games are really quick,
but at least they get going,

although 15 players isn't enough for a game
to be sustainable, you need at least twice that.

Luckily, Puff, one of Innersloth's members,
had already garnered a bit of a reputation.

He spent his early career making
Flash games on Newgrounds

and some of them did really well, as a result
he has more than 25,000 followers on Twitter
and by constantly talking about the game,

he manages to grow the community
to an average of 30 players.

It's not the best, but it's enough to continue
working on "Among Us" without having to shut down.

The first community to really
embrace "Among Us" were the South Koreans
and that was down to a streamer called Kevin Choi.
He randomly came across it on itch.io,
a platform for discovering indie games.

He streamed it with his friends at the
end of 2018 and thanks to his influence,

"Among Us" went from a few dozen players
to a few hundred players on average.

All throughout 2019, no matter the time of day,
more than 50% of the players were Korean.

And thanks to this influx of players,
"Among Us" survives until 2020

and it's here it will experience
one of the most impressive
and rapid successes observed in recent years,
a success created by a chain of events.

January 2020, a British YouTuber called
Kaif discovers the game completely by chance.

In February, the spike in players
brought by Kaif triggers an alert at Steam

which offers Innersloth the
chance to try their luck at 50% off.
In March, "Among Us" appears on Steam at 50% off.

Few players download it, but many put
it on their wishlist, including Sodapoppin.
In June, Steam prepares its summer sales

and notes that the 50% off
sale had an encouraging outcome

and suggests including the game
in the summer sales at 75% off.

Innersloth agrees and suddenly, the thousands
of people who had wishlisted the game in March

receive a notification to tell them
that "Among Us" has never been so cheap.

A large number of them take the bait and
buy the game, one of them being Sodapoppin.

Sodapoppin has 3 million followers on
Twitch and 1 million subscribers on YouTube.

He plays the game with
friends who're also influencers

and their combined reach puts the
game in front of tens of millions of people,

all while the game's a steal at $1 and half
the world is stuck at home due to Covid.

A month later, "Among Us" smashed the charts
to sell more copies per day than Fall Guys
and entered the top 5 most played games on Steam,

a list usually occupied by 5
titans which barely ever changes.

The success of "Among Us" can't
be replicated, at least not intentionally.

It's a fascinating phenomenon that only
happened 'cause a bunch of conditions,
some really improbable, were met at the same time.

The game was suddenly played by
one of the world's biggest influencers,

while Europe and America
were encouraged to stay at home.

It's a game with large teams, so
influencers play with loads of other influencers,

which multiplies the potential
audience from a single game.

There's no mechanical skill
required, almost no rules to learn

and solving a mystery with friends is
something that's universally appealing,

which means that almost every
influencer on Earth can play;

from the tryharder who hates himself
'cause he's got 20,000 hours on the same game,

to the casual who's never streamed
anything other than "Just Chatting",

to the boomer who's been
streaming a combo of "Binding of Isaac"
and "Teamfight Tactics" for the last 3 years,
everyone's a potential "Among Us" streamer.
And despite this tremendous accessibility,

the art of lying has been
cultivated since the dawn of time
and sports an infinite number of nuances.

This means that we can always
become better at "Among Us",

which therefore perfectly embodies the
principle of "Easy to learn, hard to master."

And the last condition is at the
same time the most obvious condition

and the most insignificant,
the game needs to be good,

you don't become one of the most
played games in the world by being dull.

"Among Us" is objectively a good game
and it shows, 'cause every time it had help,

whether from Kaif, Puff or Kevin Choi, it
kept most of the players that discovered it.

And it's here we see, that when you don't have
the money to pay for an advertising campaign,
it can be extremely discouraging to develop games,

'cause this game that you made
with love and that you know is good

is probably doomed to fail unless
there's an incredible alignment of the stars.
Translation and subtitles by TheDøctør

La quête du dernier secret.text: We’re in 2007.

At the time "Shadow of the Colossus"
had already been out for 2 years,

a huge success, acclaimed by
critics and the public: the works.

After tens of thousands of games,
we think everything’s been found,

even the most absurd easter egg like this hanging
garden which you can only climb in your 4th run-through

'cause you have to complete the game 3 times
to have enough stamina to climb to the top.

But the developers behind the game are known for
their tendency to leave easter eggs in their creations

and bury them really well and honestly,
with its universe as detailed as it is inexplicable,

"Shadow of the Colossus" exudes an aura of
mystery strong enough that years after its release,

some players still wander the Forbidden Lands
wondering if something’s hidden out there…
some, it would seem, even found something.

At the end of 2007,
everything’s calm on the Sony forums,

no one imagines that the biggest treasure
hunt in the forum's history is about to begin,

only, a topic's just been posted called "Quest for
the Last Big Secret" by a user named Ascadia.

In it, he explains that he's discovered
a set of clues left by the devs,

a trail that starts with
the first words in the intro.

The game starts with a mask talking
about the resonance of intersecting points
and memories etched into stone.

For others, it's just gibberish to
emphasise the mysterious side of the game,

but Ascadia doesn't agree, Ascadia’s
convinced that these words mean something.

Like everyone else, he's got no idea what
the resonance of the intersecting points is,

so he focuses on the memories etched into stone
and that's when 4 symbols catch his attention.

Stones covered with symbols is
clearly not what's missing in this game,

but they find it very suspicious that these
specific symbols seem to show up in loads of places

as they know that the different areas of the
game were made with great attention to detail.

They’re in the Shrine found at the centre of the map,
but also in ruins to the south in the desert

and in the intro on the pillars marking
the entrance to the Forbidden Lands.

For Ascadia, each symbol represents a
location on the map viewed from above,

by placing them he gets a point of convergence
smack dab on a temple buried under the desert.

In the temple, at the end of a corridor, there’s a
massive door that never opens during the game.

That December evening, Ascadia
posts his topic on the Sony forums

and asks for help to find out how to
open the door buried under the desert.

Accustomed to all kinds of crazy theories
being suggested, users are initially doubtful,

but the community's interest grows
the more Ascadia's claims are investigated.

Indeed, this symbol could very well represent the
two pillars at the entrance to the Forbidden Lands
with the pathway in the middle

and, indeed, this one looks exactly like
a ruined city to the east of the map,
recognisable by its ginormous columns.

As for the 3rd, it does
look like the central temple,

with the river that goes north and the
bridge that connects to the temple.

And it’s undeniable that
by placing them on the map,

their convergence point falls
very precisely on this particular door,

this troublesome door which
also has 4 symbols and steps,

as if the devs wanted to make sure we
understand that it’s not just a simple decoration,
but rather a passageway.

Sketches are drawn, diagrams are compared
and every day new people side with Ascadia.

An entire community that thought were done with
the game once again feels the thrill of adventure.

It’s all well and good but there’s a
spanner in the works, the 4th symbol.

Ascadia and a few others think
it represents a lake to the northwest,

except that visually
it doesn't really match.

The middle point could indeed be
the pillar which rises from the lake

and the lines around it could be
the aqueducts that join the pillar,

except that the aqueducts
are destroyed and so,

impossible to know what
they’re meant to look like.

If the devs had really
given us a trail to follow,

they wouldn't have bothered putting
a useless symbol among them,

so if no one can convincingly
pinpoint the 4th symbol...
the whole theory falls apart.

So they claim that the 4th
symbol's found by elimination,

since 3 symbols already make
it possible to find the door,

adding that from a lore
standpoint it’s logical,

'cause these symbols were probably carved at a
time when the structure on the lake wasn’t destroyed.

But they’re far from convincing
everyone on the thread.

All this back and forth caught the
attention of a user named RaisinGirl.

Like Ascadia, she thinks the 4th
symbol points to the lake but, in fact,

she saw the symbols elsewhere, a
place that many players never set foot.

In the back of the temple is a room with
a pond and a gigantic spiral staircase,

it’s around here the hero
first arrives during the intro
and there’s never really a reason to turn back

since the door at the top
of the stairs closes behind him.
It’s also the reason why, in lots of games,

there’s easter eggs hidden behind
the player at the start of a level,

'cause it’s not natural to turn
around at the start of the game.

And all along this monumental staircase,
there’s dozens and dozens of symbols,

they form lines from top to
bottom with 3 symbols per line,

each line showing a combination of
different symbols except this one,

the only one that has the same
symbol 3 times and not just any symbol,
it's the one we’re interested in.

That's when RaisinGirl realises that
when she stands in front of this line,
she's looking straight at the lake.

So she lays it out on the table
and suddenly, everyone sees it,

an easter egg hidden well enough to have eluded
all the players in the world for more than 2 years.

The staircase you go down during the
first few minutes of the game is a compass,
a compass that points straight towards the lake.

Now convinced, hundreds of players
rally behind a single objective:
find how to open this door.

In this quest, they’ll explore every square inch
of the world of "Shadow of the Colossus",

acquire a mass of knowledge
that could fill an encyclopedia

and even get a name in
the process; The Seekers,

which we'll translate here as Les Explorateurs
and my god there's a lot to explore.

When they realise that the sword
pierces the sand but rebounds off the soil,

they probe the desert metre
by metre for dozens of hours.

And when they realise that a hawk, bigger than
the others, lives in a giant tree south of the map,

they start new games over and over; 5 times,
8 times, 10 times, convinced that with enough stamina,

they’d be able to hold onto the bird long
enough for it to lead them to the next clue.

They even steal the torch from the desert
temple and take it all across the map,
hoping that its presence would trigger something.
Discoveries are even made out of game.
When "Shadow of the Colossus" came out,

it was possible to connect to a site which
showed the game's map completely covered
which could be revealed with the mouse.
The site wasn’t around very long,
in fact, the vast majority of players never saw it.
You remember RaisinGirl's discovery,

so well hidden that it's hard
to believe the devs would
put such an improbable clue in their game?
Well, the compass was there,
on a site only available for a few months in 2015
and its needle was already pointing at the lake.

There's something else that's really strange,
there's a whole bunch of magical items,

obtained only after the game
ends, items with astonishing properties;

like a sword, capable of
reflecting sunlight even in the dark

and this in a game where we’re asked to
open a door by reflecting light onto it...
but also explosive arrows, which seem to be useless

and a harpoon in a game where
only the sword can kill enemies.

We're given these items after the game ends,
they all appear in the compass room

and they have a bunch of crazy powers,
half of them having no clear use.

There’s no need to like far-fetched
theories to feel like once the game's over,

it begins to distribute the tools
necessary to obtain the Last Secret.

So each cave's explored with the light of the sword,
each wall tested with the explosive arrows

and they jump off every cliff with the parachute,
all in the hopes of finding something.
The Seekers are remarkably organised,

the thread has more than 1640
replies 6 months after starting it,

almost all of the posts suggesting new
avenues or reporting on recent explorations.
The reason it happened on this game and not another

is 'cause "Shadow of the Colossus"
is made to be like an old legend,
the kind you'd hear at the start of an RPG:

"Once upon a time, the hero beat the forces
of evil bringing peace to the kingdom."

In this kind of story, we're never
given details like who the hero is,
where they come from, why they're doing this,

it's 'cause the narration's focused
on heroism and nothing else.

With "Shadow of the Colossus", it's the same,
a guy shows up with a woman dead in his arms,
he makes a deal with a mysterious creature:

he must kill 16 Colossi and the creature
will bring the woman back to life and that's it,

there’s no other explanation until
the end of the game, there's no NPCs,
no dialogue and no secondary quests either,

just this frantic march from
one titanic battle to the next.
Everything’s as refined as possible,

'cause everything’s designed to make us feel like we’re
watching an ancient legend from front row seats.

Except, this land of legend that we’re
usually satisfied just glimpsing at its story,

this time we’re in it, we can
roam around it, we can visit its places,

we can analyse the symbols on its walls
and when we look more closely at these walls,

do we see low-res textures copied
and pasted everywhere to save time?

No, we see a myriad of details, as if this
place was real, as if it had a history.

Details and mystery, they’re the 2 magical
ingredients that create fascination in humans...

and for us who travel this world,
huh, we feel like exceptionally,

we’ve been allowed to enter somewhere that’s
only supposed to exist in our imagination.
So it's only natural that we never want to leave.

The conversation often turns to the
nature of the Last Secret of course,

the most cautious think it's a
simple congratulations from the devs,
but others aren’t afraid to dream bigger.

Thus was born one of the most
famous legends in gaming history,
a myth that travels far beyond Sony’s forum.
In the US, where this rumour's most prominent,
there’s not one college student who owns the game

that hasn’t heard that a 17th Colossus
sleeps somewhere in "Shadow of the Colossus".

But everything’s about to change,
8 months after Ascadia's first post,

someone comes to the thread
with the link to a YouTube video.

The creator of this video is one of the first in
the world to emulate "Shadow of the Colossus" on PC

and since he’s emulating, he can use hacks,
hacks that allow him to ignore all the rules.

And this YouTuber, whose
channel was deleted ages ago,

walks towards the door that contains all
the hopes and dreams of The Seekers

and like a god of mischief mocking the
rules of the universe, he goes through…
and there's nothing there.

After all the symbols, the
compass, the perfect intersection,

the closed door and the magic
items, how can there be nothing?
As the quest is now done via emulator,

a new generation of Seekers with
different skills has taken up the torch

and they made wondrous discoveries: a mountain
range lost in the fog off the edge of the map,

a gigantic dam that was left unused, or even the
nests of Colossi abandoned during development.

This second generation gained such a
comprehensive understanding of the game,

that they would be contacted by
Bluepoint many years later,

to help create the remaster
of "Shadow of the Colossus".

But all these discoveries were just
unfinished content left behind by the devs

and this wealth of knowledge
came with a very bitter realisation,
the certainty that the Last Secret didn’t exist.

As the data miners announced on the thread
that there was absolutely nothing left to find,
what did The Seekers do?

They continued to talk about
"Shadow of the Colossus" for 300 pages...

'cause the clues have always been shaky
at best and the theories far-fetched,

'cause when you're passionate, anything that lets
you continue talking about the game's a good thing,

'cause without data mining, mystery reigns
supreme and is the land in which dreams grow,

'cause sharing that feeling of being the first to set
foot somewhere with a group that has the same dreams...

is more valuable than anything that
might’ve been left behind by the devs...

'cause the quest has always been much
more important than the easter egg.

It's 2018, The Seekers have
scattered to the 4 corners of the Earth

and even the legendary thread disappeared
when Sony closed its community forums...

the quest for the Last Secret only exists in
the memories of those who took part,

but the game's just been
remade on PS4, an enormous job,

which allows a new generation
to discover a legendary game.

Could it be possible that on top of
completely overhauling the title's visuals,
the teams at Bluepoint changed something?

If anything has really changed,
it would be largely thanks to The Seekers.

Over time, their theories became stories,
and those stories became legends

and it's not every day that there's an opportunity to
remake a game of which there's so many rumours.

Is it possible that The Seekers wanted the
Last Secret so badly that they brought it to life?

This video is dedicated to William "Ascadia" Stroup
who passed away on the 9th of January 2018.
Translation and subtitles by TheDøctør

L'incroyable histoire d'Otzdarva et de l.text:
"A challenge run consists of completing a game
while imposing a challenge on yourself."

In "Dark Souls", challenge runs are particularly
popular, and the most prestigious category is,
without doubt, the ABNH for "All Bosses No Hit"

which consists of 100 per centing the game, optional
bosses and DLC included, without ever being hit...
not without dying yeah, without being hit.

There's no lack of talent in
the challenge runner community,

ABNH has been achieved on
almost all From Software's games,

but one of them still hasn't been
done several years after its release.

SquillaKilla's one of the best
challenge runners in the world,

it's not his story that we're telling,
but it's on his stream that it starts.

On a nice spring afternoon,
one of his viewers asks in chat
"When will you do All Bosses No Hit on Dark Souls 2?"
and Squilla immediately bursts out
"Dark Souls 2?
It's impossible."
Is Squilla sure of himself?
Is he speaking from experience?
He probably knows his stuff, after all,

he's the first person in the world to have completed
"Dark Souls 3" and "Bloodborne" in ABNH.

However, among the 1000s of viewers
watching Squilla that day, there's Otzdarva,

a YouTuber who spends most of his time
being an idiot in PVP on "Dark Souls 3".

He knows the series well, but he's not really
known as a challenge runner and yet,

when he hears Squilla's response, he doesn't see it
as a warning or discouragement, just a challenge.
Chapter 1: It's impossible.

Let's start by looking at the scale of the task
at hand, with its DLCs "Dark Souls 2" has 41 bosses,
by comparison, "Dark Souls 3" has 25.

41 bosses is more than "Demon Souls"
and "Bloodborne" combined.
To get to them, you've got to cross 35 zones,

which are among the most difficult levels
ever designed by From Software.

The Black Gulch, for example, the statues on
the walls spit poison, but not all of the statues,

the oil puddles on the floor are home to
nightmarish bugs, but not all the puddles,

and those unfortunate enough to
waste time looking at the statues

or the puddles are quickly scoffed up by
the worms that exit the crevices.
Great holiday huh?
Shaded Woods is another notable location,

it's a forest submerged in so much fog
that it's impossible to even see a metre away,

but it's also home to an army
of spectres, transparent spectres.

As a result, death could be running straight at
you, and you'd only see a faint sparkle in the mist.

There's insane trickery in the level
design of this game, even for a "Dark Souls".

The Forlorn also roam around this world,
a bunch of fairly unpredictable ghosts

who may or may not appear in
19 different locations in the game,

transforming a level that needs to be attentively
traversed metre by metre into a frantic chase.

Doing a no-hit run in a game with the Forlorn means
needing a backup plan for each of their 19 spawn points

and memorising those 19 plans even
though the Forlorn are relatively rare.

And in the finale of all that,
at the end of the end of the last DLC,

Frozen Eleum Loyce, the huge
and labyrinth-like city of frost,
forces the player to explore it from top to bottom,

to find the 4 knights who'll
accompany them in the final battle.

Beneath the appearance of a
peaceful city sleeping under the ice,

Frozen Eleum Loyce is one of the hardest
challenges ever created by From Software

and for the tired runner, who arrives there
after 10 hours of play, it's a nightmare.

Training starts, you need to count every
enemy in each zone, map their routes,

decide which items are essential and how to
collect them while taking the least risks.
How many different attacks does this boss have,

does it change pattern if we move away,
what's the dodge window for each attack?

That's 100s of deaths and dozens of hours of
work to get the answers to all these questions
for only a single level or a single boss.

2 months after he starts training,
Otzdarva attempts a full run for the first time.
Time: 12 hours, number of hits: 60.

Incredible for a normal player,
agonisingly far from the goal in our case...
back to work.

The Lair of the Imperfect's a problem, it's a
vast body of water where the Imperfect live.

Crazy mix between frog and dinosaur,
Imperfects can run faster than the player,

attack from distance, and their
ranged attacks are area of effect,
they've got everything to ruin a no-hit run.
After numerous deaths at the lake,

Otz and his viewers realise that it's visible
from the upper levels of the city,

so he goes on the bridge to
draw the routes of the creatures,

mapping them out to find THE route
that allows him to pass without incident.
New run: 31 hits.

The bridge that gives entry to the
Iron Keep is guarded by Armorer Dennis,
after innumerable defeats thanks to his sword,

it seems that the best way is to jump on
one of the pillars which support the bridge,

balanced on a ledge of a few centimetres
suspended above a lake of lava and it's here,

hidden behind the pillar,
that the player casts a poison spell

which slowly passes through the stones of the
pillar to poison Dennis, killing him bit by bit.

And if such an unlikely method is chosen,
it's 'cause every weapon, every spell

and every item in the game had already
been tried in this location, without success.
New run: 14 hits.

The only corridor that leads
to the top of Brume Tower

is guarded by a giant as wide as
the corridor he watches over,

you're guaranteed to lose
facing it in such a tight area,

but by attracting its attention with a well-shot
arrow, the player can get around the guard.

Once behind, you still need to pull
the lever which opens the gate,
but lava flows from the giant's shoulders

and between 2 jets of lava, there's almost exactly
the amount of time needed to open the door.
The timing needs to be perfect.
New run: 5 hits...
5 hits isn't a lot.

From here, Otz restarts the game
every time he makes a mistake,

he's left the phase where he just wants
to train, now he's chasing THE run.

It's also the time when his Twitch channel experienced
one of the most magical phenomena on the platform,

a force that unites streamer and viewer
to break records and achieve the impossible: hype.
As long as the run's promising, no one goes to bed,

the viewer that was meant to go
out to meet his friends cancels

and streamers belonging to the same community
pause their streams to come host the attempt.

Everyone wants to be there when it's the one,
everyone wants to see THE run with their own eyes.

Otz rarely exceeded 200 viewers, suddenly,
his streams start at 600 and quickly climb to 1000.

The run hasn't been beaten yet and
it's already quintupled his audience.

Come the 7th of September 2018,
he's 4 months into training and on this day,

no boss is too fast, no enemy's forgotten,
he doesn't make a single misstep

and after almost 12 hours of streaming, Otz finds
himself facing the ultimate trial in the game.

On Discord, as with Twitch,
the news spread like wildfire

and it's in front of more than 5000
viewers that Otzdarva faces the Ivory King.
The Ivory King's all but an easy final boss,

he's preceded by a long
and exhausting fight against his minions,

and when he himself enters the arena,
his attacks are ridiculously fast.

Whether the boss is difficult or not, at this
moment the runner's fighting against nerves,

when there's months of effort on the line,
it's almost impossible to play correctly,

the controller slips from his hands due to sweat
and despite the deafening noise of combat,
he hears nothing but the beating of his heart.
Fighting against your nerves means, for example,

not forgetting that if you move
too far away from the King,
he'll use his most dangerous attack, a charge,

the only attack that doesn't
always go off at the same speed.
Any other attack, Otz knows when to press on dodge,

but if the charge comes, he has to
choose between dodging on instinct

or dodging by reflex and given how quickly
it goes off, neither option's very appealing.
And as "Dark Souls 2" has absolutely no mercy,

even though the King's 2 hits from death,
Otz takes a single step back,
and that's enough to trigger the charge.
Did Otz try again the next day?
No.
He compiled his attempts, made a nice edit,

posted it all on YouTube, and didn't
talk about the run again.

A few months later, the only thing on his
channel that reminds us that he was 1 hit

away from a world first is the occasional
viewer who comes to ask "Dark Souls 2, when?"
Deep down, our runner isn't satisfied,
but he's not ready to admit it yet.

He takes 5 months off from the game,
streaming "PUBG", "Dead by Daylight",

repeating to those who insist,
that he's happy to have gone so far,

but the problem when you
die 2 hits from finishing is,

well, not only do you come up empty-handed, but
above all, you've shown the rest of the world that,

in fact, the run's doable
and that glory's within reach

and the rest of the world
didn't need to be told twice,

streamers from around the world have been
using Otzdarva's routes and strategies

for months to try to achieve the
"All Bosses No Hit" on "Dark Souls 2".

In February of 2019 the news breaks,
one of the runners just finished the game...
in 4 hits.

Relaxing's great, but no one wants to make this
many sacrifices to have 1st place stolen from them,
so for Otz, the holidays are over.
Chapter 2: Getting back to it.
With his return, hype once again takes over the community,

while he usually gravitates around 300 viewers,
Otz begins his training with 1000 viewers,

which quickly becomes 2000 if he
doesn't die during the first few hours.

The 1st attempt was carried out
with seriousness and enthusiasm,

but the 2nd would be with the hardened discipline
of an athlete preparing for the Olympic Games.

Otzdarva changes his lifestyle: he eats
healthily, sleeps at least 8 hours a night,

aware that it's not even worth
attempting the run if he's not on top form.

Countless runs failed 'cause he
read chat at the wrong time,

so he chooses the moments when he can
speak and those when only the game exists.

For each run, the parts in which he's not
perfect are noted down and every evening,

after the stream ends, he goes
back to practise them over and over.

To understand why the run's almost impossible,
you need to visualise the following:

even when a section's mastered to perfection,
there's a minute chance that something will go wrong,

a small 0.1% probability that the
enemy AI will do something weird,

that the runner's finger will slip on the controller
or that he'll blink at the worst possible moment
and this 0.1% is rolled for each step.

"Dark Souls" is a game that wants you dead,
if it's not a boss that hits in a split second,

it'll be a zombie hiding behind a crate or an archer
on top of a tower or a ghost appearing from a wall.

At every turn, in every maze, there's
something lethal waiting to ambush.
So on the road to the run,
this 0.1% grows,
it grows every second

and the only thing it needs to grow so large that it
completely halts the chances of success is time...

and unfortunately, no other "Dark Souls"
takes this long to complete, by a long shot.
Everyone knew this when the challenge was started,

but the very concept of walking around for 10 hours
in this game without ever being hit is absurd.

It's the 6th of March, a month after
coming back, the runs fail every day

and from the streamers' standpoint, as with
the viewers, we've got to fight discouragement

and the insidious idea that's
in the back of everyone's mind,

saying that Squilla was right
and that it is, in fact, impossible.

Everyone knows that Otz had once
before reached the Ivory King,

but no one knows if it was a 1 in 100 chance, and so
we've just got to be patient for it to happen again,

or a 1 in a million chance and
everyone's wasting their time.

But on this 6th of March,
we're about to get an answer,

Otz saw some friends that morning,
then came home in a good mood,

he started his stream and nothing
seemed to be able to stop him,

he cleared each section of the
game and for the 2nd time,
he reaches the Ivory King with the run still alive.
6000 people flock to the stream.

You know what, I really think it's the perfect
time to tell you about the Tearstone Ring,

this amazing item that increases the strength
of its wearer when they've got very low HP.

It's the perfect ring for a run like this
since you don't want to get hit anyway,

so you might as well get to 1 HP
and take advantage of the ring's powers.

The way to activate the ring when
you do a no-hit run is quite fun too,

you've got to get your hands on this
special hammer that poisons the wielder,
swing a few times at nothing poisoning yourself,

wait until you've lost enough health to
activate the ring, heal yourself and all that.
It's crucially important...

to have as much damage as
possible when fighting the King

'cause after a minute of combat, he enchants
his sword which then becomes longer

and if the tip of the blade needs to travel
less distance to reach the player,

then the attacks come even faster, time is
distance over speed, y'know from school.

All of this to say that Otz
forgot to activate the ring...

so the King enchanted his weapon
while still having lots of health.

If he does his fastest attack now with his
enchanted blade, it'll arrive in 25 frames,
which is around 4/10ths of a second.

Do you know how hard it is to dodge an
attack that comes in 4/10ths of a second
when you've streamed for 10 hours straight?

The sun rises on a new day, no "PUBG"
or "Dead by Daylight" in sight,

just another attempt, after all,
why should we give a crap about them

when we fail 10 seconds from the end
for the 2nd time after 6 months of work?
It happens, it happens.

The days pass by and something
terrible looms on the horizon,

something that everyone who's got a
particularly difficult task to accomplish dreads...
a time limit.

It's March, From Software's next game "Sekiro:
Shadows Die Twice" releases on the 22nd of March.

As soon as it becomes available, it'll be
the only thing Twitch has eyes for,

the thousands of viewers that motivate
Otz every day and allow him to earn a living

won't stay on a channel that
doesn't stream THE new hit game.

To retain viewers, Otz will have to stream "Sekiro",
but stopping "Dark Souls 2" for weeks or even months,

means forgetting the routes, it means getting used
to other controls, muscle memory, forgetting timings

and given the time and effort it takes to reach a
high enough level to have any chance at success,

maybe it means never getting
back the motivation to try again.

Whatever happens, he NEEDS to
succeed before "Sekiro" comes out.

12th of March, Otz slips on a
stone and falls into the sea.

The 15th, 1 second too many spent
near a basilisk turns him to stone.

The 18th, an arrow shot from afar whistles
between the trees hitting him in the shoulder

and on the 19th, a giant insect moves a
bit too far to the right blocking his path
and Otz ends up devoured by the rest of the swarm.

The fateful error's there,
always there, always lurking somewhere

and ultimately, the time limit's
almost come to an end.

It's the 21st of March and there's
24 hours left to complete the run.
Chapter 3: 24 hours for a miracle to happen.
Note: The tries were reset to 0 after the break.
21st of March 2019

Every hour there's a brush with disaster
during this specific run on the 21st of March.

For example, against the Gang Squad, a formidable
boss during which you face 3 enemies at the same time.

The only method consists of running in circles
pursued by the Soldier and the Graverobber

while systematically dodging the
arrows fired by the Explorer

and throwing poison behind you
until the 3 pursuers kick the bucket.

Otz climbs a rocky slope, dodges an arrow and while his
2 pursuers should be heading up the slope behind him,

he suddenly swivels his camera to look
to the right, the Graverobber's there,
a metre away, already preparing its attack.

Otz dodges at the last
split second and saves the run

but how did he know that the
Graverobber was no longer behind him?

Well, when it fell off the ledge earlier on,
he only heard the Soldier fall behind him...

if the Graverobber didn't make noise,
it's 'cause it stayed on the main ledge

and therefore would come at
him from an unknown angle.

There's 15 different things to watch out for during
the fight, it's the hardest fight after the Ivory King

but Otz has played so much "Dark Souls 2"
by this point, that even amid the chaos,

he's able to tell that something's wrong by
the sound of the boss's footsteps on the floor.

An hour later, we're at the
entrance to Drangleic Castle,

legend says that 1 of the 19
Forlorn spawn points is found here,

but in the months and months
of training, Otz never saw it.

It's therefore one of the only
spots where he hasn't got a plan.

It's the last chance to complete the run, for it
to spawn now would be extremely unlucky.
Note: The bottom of the stairs is blocked.

Side note, if you're discovering Otzdarva in
this video, this is a quick look through the run,

but you need to realise that
each run's this level of stress...
for 10 hours straight.
And so, as the fateful error seems to not happen...

the henchmen are eliminated, the King enters
the arena and Otz takes out a new weapon.

He always faced the Ivory King with a single blade,
Espada Ropera, the best rapier in the game,

fast, powerful, unforgiving and also
poetic as Otzdarva's Spanish.

And he always wielded the rapier with
both hands, but as the King steps forward...

the legendary rapier goes to his right hand
and an ordinary rapier appears in his left hand.

In "Dark Souls", changing weapons means changing all
the combat animations, that's all, except one thing,

if he uses 2 rapiers instead of 1,
his attacks and timings change completely.

In chat, prayers and panic gradually
give way to disbelief, then indignation,

it's your last chance and you're trying a new
weapon after a year, the hell are you doing Otz?
But this style of combat was practised off-stream.

His previous 2 losses against the
King came largely from a lack of damage.

Otz never managed to defeat the
boss before it reached phase 2,

before it enchanted its sword and the
dodge windows became ridiculous.

Wielding 2 weapons is really expensive in stamina,
but in this fight, stamina's not the problem.

The problem is demolishing the damn King
before he can cast an attack that lasts 25 frames.

So Otz throws himself into
the fight of his last chance,

with a weapon never seen before in
his 400 or so attempts on stream.

On the night of the 21st of March, a few
hours before the release of "Sekiro",

Otzdarva became the first person in the world
to complete "Dark Souls 2" in "All Bosses No Hit".

And the first thing he does right after, is grab a
chalk and write a message where the King fell.

These messages are an iconic mechanic of the
"Souls" series, they're visible to all players,
each in their own game and if they're deemed useful,

they can be upvoted and their
author then gains a few HP,

not much but just to say "Someone in
their world thanks you for this message."
Remember the Tearstone Ring?

Otz didn't forget it this time,
so he's got very little HP,

however, immediately after writing
his message, his HP skyrockets.

We can't see them, but they're there, dozens of
knights, thieves, magicians, dozens of players,

who descended at the same time
as Otz to the throne of the Ivory King

to pay homage to the one who
pushed the envelope of possibility.

And Otz's HP bar continues to fill up,
like hundreds of hugs from across the worlds.

Thanks to Otzdarva, without whom
neither the run or this video would exist.

The written version of this story can be
found on Millenium (link in the description).
And thanks for watching the video, subscribe...
and follow me on Twitter...
and maybe also on Twitch.
Bye bye.
You really don't want to help me advertise, huh?
No worries.
